sections.title: Essential Property Metrics
sections.content: Before investing in rental property, analyze the numbers thoroughly. Key metrics include net operating income (NOI), cash-on-cash return, cap rate, and internal rate of return (IRR). These help you compare properties and make informed decisions.

points.title: Cap Rate
points.description: Net operating income divided by purchase price - measures property profitability.

points.title: Cash-on-Cash Return
points.description: Annual pre-tax cash flow divided by total cash invested - your actual return on invested capital.

points.title: NOI (Net Operating Income)
points.description: Rental income minus operating expenses - doesn't include financing costs.

sections.title: Conservative Assumptions Win
sections.content: When analyzing properties, use conservative estimates for rent, vacancy rates, and expenses. The goal is to buy properties that work even in less-than-ideal conditions.

sections.title: Estimating Income and Expenses
sections.content: Research comparable properties to estimate realistic rental income. Factor in 5-10% vacancy rate and account for all expenses: property taxes, insurance, maintenance (1% of property value annually), property management (8-12% of rent), and utilities if not paid by tenants.

sections.title: Analyze a Potential Investment
steps: Research comparable rental properties in the area
Estimate realistic rental income and all operating expenses
Calculate NOI, cap rate, and cash-on-cash return
Stress test your assumptions with higher vacancy and expenses

sections.title: Location Drives Returns
sections.content: Properties in growing areas with job growth, good schools, and amenities typically perform better than those in declining areas. Focus on location first, then the property.
